================================================================================
CONFIDENCE CALIBRATION ANALYSIS
Dataset: OncNoInterruptive
================================================================================

PREDICTION OUTCOMES
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TP:  291 ( 50.0%)
TN:  264 ( 45.4%)
FP:   27 (  4.6%)
FN:    0 (  0.0%)
Total:  582

CALIBRATION ANALYSIS
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Correct predictions (n=555):
  Mean confidence:  0.9950 (SD: 0.0356)
  Median:           1.0000

Incorrect predictions (n=27):
  Mean confidence:  0.9185 (SD: 0.2158)
  Median:           0.9983

Statistical comparison (Correct vs Incorrect):
  Test: Mann-Whitney U (one-sided: correct > incorrect)
  U statistic: 13190.50
  P-value: 1.22e-11
  Effect size (rank-biserial r): +0.760
  Interpretation: large
  Significant at α=0.001: ✓ Yes

TRUE POSITIVES vs FALSE POSITIVES (Critical for Label Noise)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
True Positives (n=291):
  Mean:  0.9966 (SD: 0.0369)

False Positives (n=27):
  Mean:  0.9185 (SD: 0.2158)

Statistical comparison (TP vs FP):
  Test: Mann-Whitney U (one-sided: TP > FP)
  P-value: 2.46e-10
  Effect size (r): +0.724 (large)
  Significant at α=0.001: ✓ Yes

================================================================================
SUGGESTED TEXT FOR PAPER
================================================================================

To verify that high sensitivity reflects genuine discriminative ability rather
than uniform positive bias, we analyzed GPT-4o's prediction confidence via
log-probabilities on the OncNoInterruptive. Correct predictions exhibited
significantly higher confidence (mean logprob: 0.99, SD: 0.04)
than incorrect predictions (mean: 0.92, SD: 0.22);
Mann-Whitney U test, p < 0.001, effect size r = +0.76
(large effect).

Critically, true positive predictions showed higher confidence
(mean logprob: 1.00) than false positive predictions
(mean: 0.92), with the difference
being statistically significant (Mann-Whitney U, p < 0.001,
r = +0.72, large effect). This calibration
pattern indicates the model assigns high confidence selectively to genuine
interactions rather than indiscriminately to all positive predictions.
